thread.section_title: Painting worth millions at National Gallery slashed twice by man with a screwdriver – Metro
thread.title: Painting worth millions at National Gallery slashed twice by man with a screwdriver
thread.title_full: Painting worth millions at National Gallery slashed twice by man with a screwdriver

author: Jen
title: Painting worth millions at National Gallery slashed twice by man with a screwdriver
text:
London’s National Gallery, founded in 1824 A visitor to the National Gallery slashed a painting worth millions of pounds with a screwdriver as horrified guests looked on. 
Two assistants had to restrain him as he attacked the painting by ‘The Morning Walk’ by Thomas Gainsborough, dating back to 1785.
Three arrested over 'child abduction' after schoolgirls, 13, went missing It was left with two long scratches which penetrated the paint layers after the incident yesterday afternoon.
Staff at the gallery removed the painting from display so they could assess the damage.
The East Wing had to be evacuated while investigations took place, and did not open for two hours.
The morning walk, by Thomas Gainsborough Getty Images) A Metropolitan police spokesman said: ‘Police were called at approximately 2.10pm on March 18 to reports of a painting damaged at the National Gallery on Trafalgar Square.
‘A man has been arrested on suspicion of criminal damage. He was taken to a central London police station where he remains in custody.’
